posts.name: Ian2
posts.cooked:
Hi CD , this year over at FRC 5026 we built and deployed a new Driver Station in a Box (flight-sized Pelican case) and are quite happy with how it turned out, so we would like to share some details of why and how we made it. The version we are satisfied with is the 3rd revision in terms of computer running the software - first a Framework 13 Mainboard and now a Thinkpad T14. More details about goals, features, BOM , and the revision process attached. Please feel free to post question and comments. Thanks!

Screenshot 2025-06-01 at 12.39.05 AM 1566×748 140 KB

Screenshot 2025-06-01 at 12.39.05 AM 1566×748 140 KB

Screenshot 2025-06-01 at 12.39.05 AM 1566×748 140 KB

FRC 5026 Driver Station in a Box - May 2025.pdf (72.4 MB)

posts.name: J. Tumavitch
posts.cooked: With the case open, does it fit within the 14" maximum driver station depth? Also, a picky inspection my require that the lid not rest on the plexiglass, you might want to add a strap to keep the lid vertical.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: Total cost in the pdf is listed as less than one dollar, is that intended to be less than a thousand dollars?

posts.name: Jacob Weinberg
posts.cooked: It fit on the shelf without touching the glass at our comps this year. The only size issue is the height being ~5 inches more than most driver stations which makes the sight line of the person behind a little bit worse.

posts.name: sticky_1629
posts.cooked: We used to use something like this but a much longer rifle case (to accommodate custom button boards). Weve since downsized after realizing in charged up the lid greatly impactedour visibility of the field.

posts.name: Ian2
posts.cooked:
Yes the goal cost is meant to be <$1k. Thanks, that is a typo.

The actual cost was $650-700 depending on how the parts we already had or were regular stock are counted.

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked:
We’ve used a box for driver’s station for last three seasons.  I think it being kind of obstructive of the view could be an issue in some certain games, however, I think we haven’t had any trouble with that, usually the driver is standing to a side, and they can move enough to see well.

The lid width is something to consider if you don’t want to break the depth limit.  I know ours is borderline, but we’ve not been asked about it by inspectors to my knowledge.   It fits well within in while the lid is closed! I wouldn’t expect problems unless it is hanging further off the shelf.

Don’t forget to add velcro to the outside of the box to attach to the shelf.  Since that surface was uneven, we screwed some flat “skis” to the bottom to attach the velcro to.  Not sure how the pelican cases would do without modifying it.

I’ve definitely seen teams with wider cases, like the rifle ones, but I like the smaller one we have (not pelican, it used to be an old camera/equipment case made of wood/metal).  But because of the narrow width it can feel like cords will get in way, so we mostly have the habit of stowing everything below between matches.  Our setup is pretty much exactly like yours, but it is sometimes an annoyance not to have something more permanent on connections, and drivers have to be careful setting up that they reconnect.
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
